info.name: API documentation
info.description:
# üìÑ Get started here

This template contains a boilerplate for documentation that you can quickly customize and reuse.

---

# üîñ How to use this template

Start with a brief overview of what your API offers.

The **Inventory and Order Management API** provides tools and resources that enable you to **manage products, customers, and orders efficiently**.  
It supports:

- Creating and retrieving products
    
- Managing customer information
    
- Placing orders with automatic stock deduction
    
- Monitoring system metrics via Spring Actuator
    

Key features include:

- JWT-based authentication
    
- Optimistic locking to prevent overselling
    
- Soft deletes for data recovery
    

---

## üöÄ Getting started guide

To start using the **Inventory and Order Management API**, you need to:

### üõ†Ô∏è Set Up the Environment

- Ensure you have **Java 17**, **Maven**, and **MySQL 8.0+** installed.
    
- Clone the repository and configure the MySQL database as described in the [README.md](https://README.md).
    

### üîê Obtain a JWT Token

- You must use a valid JWT token to send requests to protected API endpoints.
    
- Register a new user or log in via `/api/auth/register` or `/api/auth/login` to get a token. (See [Authentication](#authentication) section below)
    

### ‚ö†Ô∏è Understand API Constraints

- The API only responds to **HTTPS-secured** communications.
    
- Requests over HTTP return an **HTTP 301 redirect** to the HTTPS version.
    
- Responses are returned in **JSON format**.
    
- Errors are returned in the JSON body as a `message` key.
    

### üß™ Test the API

- Use the provided Postman Collection: **InventoryOrderAPI.postman_collection.json**
    
- Start with unauthenticated endpoints, then use your JWT token to access protected endpoints like `/api/products` or `/actuator/metrics`.
    

---

## üîê Authentication

The **Inventory and Order Management API** uses **JWT (JSON Web Token)** for authentication.

### üîë How to Get a JWT Token

Send a POST request to `/api/auth/login` with:

``` json
{
  "username": "john",
  "password": "secret"
}

 ```

You will receive a JWT token like:

```
eyJhbGciOiJIUzUxMiJ9.eyJzdWIiOiJqb2huIiwiaWF0IjoxNjgzMjUyNjU5LCJleHAiOjE2ODMzMzkwNTl9...

 ```

### üì§ Using the JWT Token

Include the token in the request header:

```
Authorization: Bearer <your_token_here>

 ```

### üö´ Authentication error response

- `401 Unauthorized`: Invalid or missing JWT token
    

---

## üìâ Rate and usage limits

### üìä Rate Limits

API access rate limits apply **per user** (tracked via JWT token).  
The default limit is:

- **100 requests per minute per user**
    
- `429 Too Many Requests`: Rate limit exceeded. Please try again later.
    

### üßæ Headers

Each API response includes the following headers:

| Header | Description |
| --- | --- |
| `X-RateLimit-Limit` | The maximum number of requests permitted per minute (100) |
| `X-RateLimit-Remaining` | The number of requests remaining in the current window |
| `X-RateLimit-Reset` | Time when the current rate window resets (in epoch seconds) |

### üõë 503 Response

An `HTTP 503 Service Unavailable` response indicates a spike in API traffic.  
The server typically recovers in under five minutes.  
For persistent issues or other 5XX errors, contact support.

---

## ‚ùì Need some help?

- Review our [README.md](https://README.md) for full setup instructions and endpoint documentation.
    
- Use the provided Postman Collection: **InventoryOrderAPI.postman_collection.json** to explore and test the API.
    
- Have questions or need to report a bug? Visit our GitLab Issues page.
    
- For monitoring endpoints, see the [Spring Boot Actuator documentation](https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/current/actuator-api/html/).
    

---

Let me know if you'd like this in Markdown format for direct import into Postman or for use in a Git repo!

item.name: Customer

query.description:
Optional. A workspace ID in which to create the collection.

If you do not include this query parameter, the system creates the collection in your "My Workspace" workspace.

request.description:
Creates a collection using the [Postman Collection v2 schema format](https://schema.postman.com/json/collection/v2.1.0/docs/index.html). Include a `collection` object in the request body that contains the following required properties:

*   `info` ‚Äî An **object** that contains the following properties:
    *   `name` ‚Äî A **string** value that contains the collection's name.
    *   `schema` ‚Äî A **string** that contains a URL to the collection's schema. For example, the `https://schema.getpostman.com/collection/v1` URL.
*   `item` ‚Äî An **object** that contains the HTTP request and response information.
    *   `request` ‚Äî An **object** that contains the collection's request information. For a complete list of values, refer to the `definitions.request` entry in the [collection.json schema file](https://schema.postman.com/json/collection/v2.1.0/collection.json). If you pass an empty object for this value, the system defaults to an untitled GET request.

**Note:**

*   For a complete list of available property values for this endpoint, use the following references available in the [collection.json schema file](https://schema.postman.com/json/collection/v2.1.0/collection.json):
    *   `info` object ‚Äî Use the `definitions.info` entry.
    *   `item` object ‚Äî Use the `definitions.items` entry.
*   For all other possible values, refer to the [collection.json schema file](https://schema.postman.com/json/collection/v2.1.0/collection.json).

request.description:
Updates a collection using the [Postman Collection v2 schema format](https://schema.postman.com/json/collection/v2.1.0/docs/index.html). Include a `collection` object in the request body that contains the following required properties:

- `info` ‚Äî An **object** that contains the following properties:
    - `name` ‚Äî A **string** value that contains the collection's name.
    - `schema` ‚Äî A **string** that contains a URL to the collection's schema. For example, the `https://schema.getpostman.com/collection/v1` URL.
- `item` ‚Äî An **object** that contains the HTTP request and response information.
    - `request` ‚Äî An **object** that contains the collection's request information. For a complete list of values, refer to the `definitions.request` entry in the [collection.json schema file](https://schema.postman.com/json/collection/v2.1.0/collection.json). If you pass an empty object for this value, the system defaults to an untitled GET request.

**Note:**

- For a complete list of available property values for this endpoint, use the following references available in the [collection.json schema file](https://schema.postman.com/json/collection/v2.1.0/collection.json):
    - `info` object ‚Äî Use the `definitions.info` entry.
    - `item` object ‚Äî Use the `definitions.items` entry.
- For all other possible values, refer to the [collection.json schema file](https://schema.postman.com/json/collection/v2.1.0/collection.json).
    

### Important

Use caution when using this endpoint. The system will replace the existing collection with the values passed in the request body.
